resources.string: Tip: you can also open it from Reports.
MAP + CVP + CO. Output in Wood Units or dyn·s·cm⁻⁵.
CPO/CPI with MAP + CO (+ BSA optional).
Calculates cardiac output (CO) using either the Fick method or thermodilution runs. The result is shared with the other tools (SVR, PVR, cardiac power, PAPI).

FORMULAS • SVR (Wood Units) = (MAP − CVP) / CO • SVR (dyn·s·cm⁻⁵) = SVR(WU) × 80 UNITS / NOTES • MAP and CVP (or RAP) in mmHg; CO in L/min. • If non-invasive MAP: MAP ≈ (SBP + 2×DBP)/3. • Use a consistent CO method for comparability.
FORMULAS • CPO (W) = (MAP × CO) / 451 • CPI (W/m²) = CPO / BSA UNITS / NOTES • MAP in mmHg; CO in L/min. • 451 is the conversion factor to Watts. • Always interpret in clinical context.
FORMULAS • PAPi = (PASP − PADP) / RAP UNITS / NOTES • PASP, PADP, RAP in mmHg. • RAP = right atrial pressure (RAP/CVP).
Ready to generate a PDF with date/time and completed calculations.
Perform at least one calculation to enable the report.
• Swan-Ganz pressures + CO\n• If using Fick: arterial + pulmonary artery sample (SvO₂) and Hb

• Swan-Ganz pressures: RAP (RA), PA (PASP/PADP/mPAP) and PCWP (wedge), ideally at end-expiration. • If using Fick: systemic arterial sample and mixed venous sample from pulmonary artery (PA). Label sampling site and send for co-oximetry/blood gas for SaO₂/SvO₂ and Hb. • MAP: preferably invasive arterial line; alternatively non-invasive BP and MAP ≈ (SBP + 2×DBP)/3. • CO: use a consistent method (thermodilution or Fick) for resistances and power.
Do you want to clear all fields and results?
Arterial oxygen saturation. Ideally measured from arterial blood gas or co-oximetry. Typical values: 95–100%.
Mixed venous oxygen saturation. Ideally a pulmonary artery sample (Swan–Ganz catheter). Typical values: 60–80%.
Hemoglobin concentration. Impacts arterial/venous O₂ content used in the Fick equation. Common units: g/dL or g/L.
Heart rate in beats per minute (bpm). Used to derive stroke volume from cardiac output.
Too high; please change to proceed.
MDCalc-style interface: weight, height, SaO₂, SvO₂, Hb, HR and age. Estimated VO₂ adjusts automatically by age; advanced option for measured VO₂.
SvO₂ (mixed) – pulmonary artery sample (PA) via Swan-Ganz
CPO = (MAP × CO) / 451. CPI = (MAP × CI) / 451 when BSA is available.
Preferred: invasive arterial line. Alternative: MAP ≈ (SBP + 2×DBP) / 3.
From right-heart cath: thermodilution (average) or Fick.
Only needed if you want CPI (CPO indexed to BSA).
Review the required fields (Mean Arterial Pressure, Central Venous Pressure, and Cardiac Output).

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR) estimates resistance to flow in the systemic circulation.

Formula:
SVR (WU) = (MAP − CVP) / CO
SVR (dyn·s·cm⁻⁵) = SVR (WU) × 80

MAP: mean arterial pressure
CVP: central venous pressure
CO: cardiac output
MAP, CVP and CO are required.
Right atrial pressure / central venous pressure (RAP)
Measure on pulmonary artery tracing via Swan-Ganz. Record PASP.
Measure on pulmonary artery tracing via Swan-Ganz. Record PADP.
Measure in right atrium via Swan-Ganz (or CVP). Ideally end-expiration.
PASP, PADP and RAP are required.
PASP cannot be lower than PADP. Please verify values.
PAPi < 0.9 suggests higher risk of right ventricular dysfunction (per reference tool threshold).
PAPi ≥ 0.9: no high-risk criterion by this threshold (interpret in clinical context).

PAPi (Pulmonary Artery Pulsatility Index) = (PASP − PADP) / RAP.

PASP: pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
PADP: pulmonary artery diastolic pressure.
RAP: right atrial pressure.
Calculates pulmonary vascular resistance using mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP), pulmonary artery wedge pressure (PAWP), and cardiac output (CO).

Pulmonary resistance calculations based on right-heart catheterization hemodynamics. PVR (Pulmonary Vascular Resistance, WU) = (mPAP − PAWP) / CO TPR (Total Pulmonary Resistance, WU) = mPAP / CO Conversion: dyn·s·cm⁻⁵ = WU × 80 mPAP: mean pulmonary artery pressure PAWP: pulmonary artery wedge pressure (surrogate of left atrial pressure) CO: cardiac output
Mean pulmonary artery pressure measured during right heart catheterization (mmHg).
Pulmonary artery wedge pressure (also called PCWP), used as a surrogate of left atrial pressure (mmHg).
Pulmonary blood flow (Qp). In the absence of shunt, Qp ≈ CO. If you have measured Qp separately, you may enter it here.
Wood units (WU) are the standard for PVR. CGS units are dyn·s·cm⁻⁵ (WU × 80).
Missing data: mPAP, PAWP and Qp/CO are required.
mPAP − PAWP must be > 0. Check pressures.

This application is intended exclusively for educational and instructional purposes. The calculations and recommendations are supportive tools and may depend on input quality, clinical conditions and assumptions. They do not replace comprehensive medical evaluation, clinical guidelines, institutional protocols or clinical judgment.

The user (healthcare professional) is solely responsible for: • Verifying entered data (units, measurement source, timing). • Interpreting results in the patient’s clinical context. • Making diagnostic and therapeutic decisions based on professional judgment. • Complying with local regulations and institutional policies.

The developer assumes no responsibility for direct or indirect damages arising from the use of this application. It is recommended to cross-check results with reliable sources and, when applicable, reference methods.
Avoid entering identifiable patient information if not necessary. If you choose to do so, you are responsible for handling it in accordance with applicable law.
I have read and accept the terms. I understand that the use and interpretation of the information is my professional responsibility.
Notice: decision-support tool. Does not replace clinical judgment.
Too high; please change to proceed.
Manage your clinical database securely. Access patient profiles, hemodynamic history, and generate detailed PDF reports for your clinical practice.
Ideal for quick hemodynamic checks where data persistence and report generation are not required.
Data entered in Quick Calculations mode is not stored. Use the Patients module to save information.
Charts will appear here once you have multiple studies saved for this patient.
Tip: Export reports from the correct clinical context to ensure traceability.
No studies have been saved for this patient yet. Create a new study to start the workshop.
No hemodynamic data is available for the latest study.
At least two studies with data are required to show trends.
mPAP and PAWP increase in parallel: possible rising post-capillary contribution (correlate with volume status and left-sided filling pressures).
mPAP and PVR increase with non-increasing PAWP: possible rising pre-capillary load.
RAP rising with falling CI/CPO: possible right-sided congestion with reduced forward flow.
PVR decreasing with improving CI/CPO: pattern consistent with favorable hemodynamic response.
Choose a study to export an individual PDF.
Autogenerated. You may edit if needed.
Tap the icon to pick a date.
Select one or more predefined tags.
This code already exists. Choose another or generate a new one.
Out of typical range; please verify.
Select predefined clinical tags. Labels change by language, while the database stores stable internal keys.
Shock context: hemodynamic evaluation or reassessment.
Authentication is not available on this device.
Set up biometrics or a device lock to use this feature.
A security update is required for authentication.
Authentication is not supported on this device.
Too many attempts. Try again later.
No device lock is set up.
Unable to process authentication. Try again.
A security update is required for authentication.
To view or edit patients, confirm your identity.
Protected quick access. No identifying data is shown.
Authenticate to open the last patient
Do you want to delete this patient? This action cannot be undone.
No patients yet. Tap + to create one.
A name clinicians can easily recognize.
Please review the fields marked in red.
Quick calculation mode. No patient data is linked.
Patient study mode. Results can be linked to a study.
Ready to export an anonymous report. No patient identifiers will be included.
Enter at least one TD run > 0.
Tip: you can still enter Weight/Height above (optional) to compute CI/BSA.
Some calculations are still missing. If you exit now, the study will be saved with the information available. Do you want to exit the hemodynamic workshop?
Recommended workshop entry: start with Cardiac output (CO).
You have performed some calculations, but the workshop is not complete. Do you want to save the study as it is or discard it?
Weight and height look out of the usual range. Please verify.
Weight looks out of the usual range. Please verify.
Height looks out of the usual range. Please verify.
Date of birth cannot be in the future.
Date of birth is outside a plausible range.
Both CI and PCWP are required to display the chart.

Hemodynamic Hemodynamic interpretation Clinical considerations Measurement notes • Confirm proper transducer leveling/zeroing (phlebostatic axis) and end-expiratory reading.
• Review the PCWP waveform (large V-waves, under-/over-wedging) and its relationship to pulmonary artery pressures.
• Interpret PCWP/CI in the context of mechanical ventilation, high PEEP, arrhythmias, and rapid changes in volume/vasoactive support.
Profile I · Warm and dry Profile II · Warm and wet Profile III · Cold and dry Profile IV · Cold and wet
CI ≥ %1$.1f L/min/m² and PCWP ≤ %2$.0f mmHg: preserved perfusion without significant congestion. CI ≥ %1$.1f L/min/m² and PCWP > %2$.0f mmHg: preserved perfusion with congestion (elevated filling pressures). CI < %1$.1f L/min/m² and PCWP ≤ %2$.0f mmHg: hypoperfusion without marked congestion. CI < %1$.1f L/min/m² and PCWP > %2$.0f mmHg: hypoperfusion with congestion (higher-risk hemodynamic profile).
• Profile generally consistent with hemodynamic stability.
• If symptomatic, integrate with RAP/PAP, oxygenation, echocardiography, and clinical examination.
• If values are discordant with the clinical picture, prioritize measurement quality checks.
• Congestion with preserved perfusion is common in acute decompensated heart failure.
• Review PCWP for large V-waves (e.g., mitral regurgitation) or reduced left atrial compliance.
• Integrate with RAP and PAP for biventricular congestion and pulmonary edema risk.
• Trend awareness: rising PCWP with falling CI suggests hemodynamic deterioration.
• Hypoperfusion with low/normal PCWP: consider low preload, increased afterload, RV failure, or mechanical causes (e.g., tamponade).
• Correlate with SvO2, lactate, and cardiac power output (CPO) when available.
• Prefer dynamic assessment of preload responsiveness when clinically appropriate.
• Hypoperfusion with elevated filling pressures is a high-risk profile consistent with cardiogenic shock physiology.
• Correlate with MAP, lactate, SvO2, CPO, and RV markers (RAP, PAPi) when available.
• Consider urgent escalation and cause-directed management per institutional protocols.
• Reassess serially after interventions to document hemodynamic response.
CI and PCWP are required to display the chart.
Trajectory by CI (Y-axis) and PCWP (X-axis) across studies.
CI and PCWP are required in at least one study to plot the chart.
